unnormalised: Gastroenterology, or as I like to call it, "the gut-wrenching truth of your insides," isn't exactly a barrel of laughs. But hey, if we can't joke about a colonoscopy prep, what can we joke about? So, let's dive into the world of digestive woes, shall we? Think of your stomach as a stubborn auto-rickshaw driver in Delhi traffic – always honking, occasionally sputtering, and sometimes demanding unreasonable fares (in the form of spicy samosas).

unnormalised: Firstly, IBS (Irritable Bowel Syndrome) – the drama queen of the digestive system. It’s like having a Bollywood saga playing out in your tummy. One minute it's constipation, the next it's diarrhea, and all the while, your stomach's belting out dramatic dialogues. Diagnosing IBS can be tricky; often, Dr. Sharma at AIIMS will suggest cutting out gluten or lactose, which basically means no more naan or chai! Is that really living?

unnormalised: Then there's acid reflux, that burning sensation that makes you feel like a tiny volcano is erupting in your chest. It's the culinary equivalent of watching a bad reality TV show – you know you shouldn’t be eating that extra plate of biryani at 11:00 PM, but you just can't help yourself. Try some antacids, or better yet, just sleep sitting upright like a guru meditating on Mount Kailash.

unnormalised: And let's not forget ulcers, those pesky sores that feel like tiny demons are tap-dancing on your stomach lining. Usually caused by H. pylori or excessive use of painkillers, they're a painful reminder that even the strongest stomachs have their limits. Treatment often involves antibiotics and PPIs (proton pump inhibitors), which, let’s be honest, sound like something out of a sci-fi film. Remember that Rs. 5000 endoscopy the doc recommended? Might be worth it!

unnormalised: So, there you have it – a light-hearted (and slightly irreverent) look at the fascinating world of gastroenterology. Remember, if your gut's acting up, don't just Google your symptoms and self-diagnose with some obscure disease you found on WebMD. Consult a proper gastroenterologist like Dr. Patel. After all, your stomach deserves better than random internet advice and copious amounts of ajwain. Maybe prepone that appointment you have been putting off?
